text: Family Member: Okay. Doctor: The insurance part may take a little bit longer because, uh, I can’t, I don’t know enough about insurance to predict. It’s crazy. It’s silly. But that’s, you know. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: But the drug’s like twelve thousand dollars a month. Family Member: Hum. You said one was going to be coming out on the market soon? Doctor: Oh. I’m sorry. I jumped, I jumped around. So, uh, I jumped to the radium thing. But there’s another trial that’s coming up. Family Member: Maybe put that down so you can focus some again on the radium study. Doctor: So I, I was going to talk to you about a radioactive thing we have that’s very specifically targeted the prostate cancer cells. Uh, I keep telling folks about it, and then it keeps taking too long, and we haven’t opened the trial yet. I thought we were going to open it in August. It’s now December. Family Member: What’s the name of it? Patient: Radium. Doctor: Well, no, the radium’s a different thing. So the radium, uh, this is called, this is just, it’s P-S-M-A, targeted, uh. Family Member: But it hasn’t gotten here yet? They looking at it in kind of-? Doctor: So, they’ve, they’ve tested it in Europe in a, in a weird way. So in Europe, the doctors there are allowed to, if they think something could work, they’re allowed to just give it to people. They don’t need FDA kind of approval.

text: Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: You want us to print it? Patient: Seven to twenty nine. Doctor: Yeah, it is, it is a mess. Patient: I haven't read it before. Doctor: I mean, most of it is, um, I say usual, you might get tired, because tired is always tops of everything. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: We always got to watch your blood counts, because we always got to watch your blood counts. And that means white cells, red cells, platelets, and then of course, liver and kidney numbers. But that's blood tests. So you don't necessarily feel bad from that. We do know that some patients, their platelets go down a little bit. And that in some other patients, you might get a little bit of stomach upset. So not like full blown oh my gosh, you can't eat anything. And if that is the case, then we would have to, you know, modify the medication dose. But you can get a slight, you know, nausea or upset stomach. So we'd have to figure out how that plays with you. Other than that, that’s about it, so it's basically another hormone pill. So Xtandi, tackles one pathway of the receptor. This pill is another pathway. They are somewhat related, but this is not a chemo, it's actually another hormone. Yeah. So we're just trying to make sure you're super castrated, and then some, and then some. Patient: There’s that euphemism for the Prius. Patient: So, how does it affect my heart? Doctor: So obviously, we have to make sure that we take care of it, it shouldn't affect there's no direct effect, you know, it's not like, here's the chemo and Oh, boy. The Xtandi is, you know, always has a potential for heart issues, because we can't say that it doesn't, because anything that touches that testosterone pathway puts you in more of a menopause and accelerates heart disease. But that's true with your, you know, Lupron, that's true for all the other pills you've been on. Unfortunately, that's the main sort of active drug with all of this with prostate cancer. So that's the tough part. This one shouldn't have a cardiac thing. But again, this is a study. So if you do have a worsening cardiac thing that's reportable, because we would want to make sure that no other person has that. Patient: So they don't know that? Doctor: Oh, no, this is why it's a study. I mean, this is- you’re guinea pig, once again, you know, like you tell us what's going on. But it isn't like this is a chemo or something that we're really worried that this might worsen heart disease. But it's always this- every time you fool around with the hormone receptors, you know, it can worsen heart disease in general. So I don't know about this particular combo, but that's why it's on a study and not me just go in here, take this.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Like next Tuesday or next Wednesday. But I think either way, because of this anemia that has come back, uh, the trial at the very least will require us to stop the medication until the hemoglobin increases. Patient: Hum. Family Member: So are there other things that he can do like, say, for instance, you know, maybe take an iron or, but are there food products that he can eat that might help with increasing, uh, his blood? Doctor: Well, there’s many, you know, causes for anemia. And the only one of them that is helped by iron is iron-deficiency anemia. Iron-deficiency anemia is typically, one, caused by bleeding from somewhere. Family Member: Hum. Doctor: So, uh, I really don’t think you have the iron-deficiency anemia, and so, uh, I don’t think that will help that much, unfortunately. You know? I wouldn’t discourage you from taking iron if you want to. Patient: Um hum. Okay. Doctor: Or if you want to eat iron-rich foods, uh, like- Family Member: But you’re thinking this is basically because of the medication? The study medication? Doctor: Yeah. I’m pretty sure. I’m pretty sure because, I mean, he actually had some degree of mild anemia before he went on the study. Part of that could have been from the cancer of the bone or marrow, specifically, but clearly when he went on the drug, it got worse, and it dropped back one to two points. So, uh, but you might need a transfusion, however. But that’s a possibility. Patient: Um hum. Okay. Doctor: So as of today, you know, stopping the . Okay? Uh, let’s plan to do, uh, forgot what the lab was. Is it K___?

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um okay. Patient: Are they, did E_ --- Doctor: And, then, you know, I would say your brother who has prostate cancer he probably should get tested because it’s, you know, it’s possible he has the same gene mutation, um, inherited because it is a risk factor. So, from the standpoint of your family, that’s my advice – they get tested. For you personally, what does it mean? (pause) Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We’ve also been doing clinical studies in a weird way with giving men testosterone Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Who become resistant to hormones. Patient: Yeah, you talked about that. Doctor: And one of the things we’re observing is men who have BRCA2 mutation seem to respond really well to getting testosterone. We’re trying to figure out why. We just put in a big grant to kind of study this. So, so, we are about to, uh, have some trials where we’re – one of our trials is, if a guy has a mutation in this and he maybe responds to testosterone and he maybe responds to immune therapy, what if we give him both? Um. So, that’s a trial down the road that’s going to open up, um, probably in the next six months. We can talk more about that. Patient: If you get the grant? Doctor: No, we got that already. Patient: Oh.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
